quizzes.title: History Quiz: Year and State
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, chernenko, gorbachev. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: On May 23, 1934, bank robbers Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow were gunned down in this state.
What memorial was dedicated on May 30, 1922?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lincoln Memorial

questions.question: What state became the 32nd state of the Union on May 11, 1858?
This Yankee legends consecutive game streak of 2,130 came to an end on May 2, 1939.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lou Gehrig

questions.question: The U.S. acquired Spanish Florida on the 22th day of this month in 1819.
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle was born in this year, on May 22.
Three of these events took place at the beginning of the year in which they occurred. Which is the odd one?

options.text: First McDonalds opened in Soviet Union (1990)

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cary Grant died (1986)

questions.question: What blockbuster movie opened on May 25, 1977?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Star Wars

questions.question: Just one of these events took place on October 13.

options.text: Isaac Singer won the Nobel Prize.
Professional revolutionary Che Guevara was executed in Bolivia.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Italy declared war on Germany.

questions.question: Hong Kong ceded to the British and John F. Kennedy was inaugurated on this day.
Mikhail Gorbachev was picked to succeed Chernenko in this year.
Dalai Lama began his exile on March 31, 1950.
What did Levi Strauss receive a patent for on May 20, 1873?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Denim Pants with Copper Rivets

questions.question: England declared war on France on 15 May 1756 starting the Seven Years War which was also known as the French and Indian War in America.
On May 14, 1904, the first Olympic Games to be held in the U.S. opened in what city?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: St. Louis

quizzes.title: Sports Quiz: Year and Month
quizzes.description: Test your sports knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Sports, jesse, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In this year George Martin, English producer of The Beatles, was born, Fox Film bought the Movietone system for recording sound onto tape, and Joe Paterno, longtime coach of Pennsylvania State Universitys college football team was born.
Patriot Day is celebrated in this month in the USA, in memory of the casualties in the September 11 attacks.
In this year the Green Bay Packers won the Super Bowl, Foolish Games/You Were Meant for Me by Jewel was the number 2 song, and the movie Titanic came out.
In this year Cy Young threw the first perfect game in modern baseball history, movie star Cary Grant was born, and Give My Regards to Broadway was initiated in a Broadway theater.
In this year the U.S.A. upset the Soviet Union in Olympic hockey, Call Me by Blondie was the #1 song, and Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back came out.
In this year Elvis Presley appeared on the Ed Sullivan show for the third time, the Brooklyn Dodgers moved to L.A., and The Bridge on the River Kwai was released.

In this year the New York Jets of the American Football League beat the favored Baltimore Colts of the National Football League 16-7 in Super Bowl III, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid came out, and Stevie Wonder came out with I Dont Know Why.
In what month are the World Health Day and Buddhas Birthday celebrated?
In this year Notre Dame beat UCLA 71-70 in mens college basketball ending the Bruins 88-game winning streak, The Way We Were by Barbra Streisand was the number 1 song, and The Godfather II came out.
The first volume of this novel was published on September 30, 1868.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Little Women

questions.question: In this year sprinter Jesse Owens was born, the Philadelphia Athletics won the World Series, and Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde came out as a silent film.

In this year the Dow Jones Industrial Average reached its lowest level of the Great Depression, bottoming out at 41.22, Tarzan the Ape Man opened,and the Winter Olympics were held in Lake Placid, New York.
One of these four people was not born on April 1.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: King George II of Greece

questions.question: In this year Casablanca premiered at the Hollywood Theater in New York City, Paul McCartney was born, and the St. Louis Cardinals beat the New York Yankees in the World Series.
In this month Martin Luther King, Jr. Day is celebrated in the United States and Australia Day is celebrated in Australia.

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Month and Thermopylae
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, independence, caesar. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What Renaissance humanist historian coined the term Middle Age?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Flavio Biondo

questions.question: Which of these was the legal successor to the classical Roman Empire?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Eastern Roman Empire

questions.question: In this month the USA celebrates its Independence Day.
When was this headline breaking news:
Who created the concept of the Dark Ages in the 1330s?
Napoleon Bonaparte was born in this month, which marks the official end of the Second World War.
This is the World Blindness Awareness Month, and Halloween is celebrated on its last day. It is also called Red because of the Russian revolution of 1917.
Valentines Day is celebrated in this month, which is also Black History Month in Canada and the United States.
In the historic Battle of Thermopylae, who is Ephialtes?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A greek traitor

questions.question: When did the West Roman Empire cease to exist?
In this month, Julius Caesar was killed, and International Womens Day and Saint Patricks Day are celebrated.
Thermopylae, the site of the historic Battle of Thermopylae, was what type of area?

options.text: It was a wide open plain

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It was a narrow pass

questions.question: What was the language of science in the ancient world?
Which of these statements is true about the Battle of Artemisium?

options.text: It was the battle where king Darius was defeated
It was the final naval battle that destroyed the Greek fleet
It was the battle before the sacking of Athens
It was the naval battle that  took place at Thermopylae

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It was the naval battle that  took place at Thermopylae

questions.question: In many countries Labor Day is observed in this month, which is also dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary in Roman Catholic tradition.

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Paleozoic and Period
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, reptile, content. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What event signaled the end of the Paleozoic?

options.text: A large mass extinction at the end of the Permian period

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A large mass extinction at the end of the Permian period

questions.question: When did the Christianisation of Germanic tribes begin?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: in the 4th century

questions.question: What period in the Middle Ages marked a renewed interest in Classical Antiquity?
Mammal like reptiles were common by the end of the Paleozoic.
The oldest confirmed fossil of a reptile belonged to what animal?
The atmospheric oxygen content during the late Paleozoic era was greater than that of today.
Which of the following is not a period of the Paleozoic era?
When did Boniface III, the first Bishop of Rome, begin to bear the title Pope?
What term refers to the raise in biodiversity that occurred during the early Paleozoic era?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cambrian Explosion

questions.question: In which country did the name Gustav originate?
The first terrestrial plants evolved during the Silurian period. Which of the following is an example of these primitive floras?
Which animal is often used as an index fossil for identifying Paleozoic strata?
What does the term “Paleozoic” mean?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ancient life

questions.question: When did a pandemic, known as the Plague of Justinian, afflict the Byzantine Empire?
When did the great migration of the Slavs begin?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: in the 7th century

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Sweden and Britain
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, field, gustav. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: King Carl XVI Gustaf ascended to the throne on September 15, 1973, after the death of his grandfather, King Gustaf VI Adolf. Carl XVI Gustaf, who is probably best known as the presenter of the Nobel Prizes,

Charles X Gustav (Karl X Gustaf) was a descendant of the House of Palatinate-Zweibrücken. On July 10, 1655, he left Sweden to engage in the Second  Northern War (1655-1660) which started with the occupation of Dünaburg by the Swedes on July 1, 1655. Eventually his armies occupied most of this European country.
This Swedish city was founded by Gustav II Adolf, who was known by the Latinized name Gustavus Adolphus and was King of Sweden from 1611 until his death.
Hitler, like several conquerors before him, faced the daunting task of crossing the English Channel and invading Britain. Which of the following was the only conqueror to successfully do this?

options.text: Philip II and the Spanish Armada

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William I of Normandy

questions.question: Gustav III of Sweden, a member of a House of Holstein-Gottorp, was assassinated at a midnight masquerade at the Royal Swedish Opera in Stockholm on March 16, 1792. This became the basis of Eugene Scribes libretto for the opera Un Ballo in Maschera (A Masked Ball). Who composed the opera?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Giuseppe Verdi

questions.question: Which of these are not characteristic of Gothic architecture?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: dark or brown walls

questions.question: Gustaf V of Sweden, the last Swedish king to intervene directly in the politics of the country, was also a devoted sportsman, playing in tournaments under the pseudonym Mr G. In 1980, King Gustaf was elected into the International Hall of Fame of this sport.
In which of the following present-day countries was Gothic language spoken?
Gustav has been a common name for Swedish monarchs since the reign of Gustav Vasa or Gustav I.
The final German goal of the Battle of Britain was a successful invasion of Britain, but before that the Germans had to achieve this intermediate goal.

options.text: Gaining air superiority over the English channel so that a German invasion fleet could cross the channel protected by the German air force.
Destroying the British arms manufacturing industries
Destroying the French underground guerrilla warfare
Defeating the British surface fleet in a great sea battle

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gaining air superiority over the English channel so that a German invasion fleet could cross the channel protected by the German air force.

questions.question: Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden voluntarily abdicated in the winter of 1808 when Russia invaded Sweden and Denmark declared war. By early 1809 Sweden lost almost a third of the Swedish realm and a quarter of its population to the Russians. The territory which the Russians occupied is in this modern country.
Most of the powers of the Swedish monarchy died with Gustaf VI Adolf who had two major interests in life besides his country: archeology and this science.
Never in the field of human conflict has so much been owed by so many to so few.’ In this famous quote by Winston Churchill who were the few he was referring to?

options.text: Anti-German spies in France and Belgium

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: British fighter pilots

questions.question: Which of these was an advantage the British had in the Battle of Britain?

options.text: The British Army was a constant threat to make raids on German supply facilities and bases in France.
The British Navy was able to shoot down many German planes as they flew over the English Channel.
The British had a larger number of fighter planes than the Germans.
British pilots forced to parachute from damaged planes often landed on friendly territory and could return to action soon afterward.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: British pilots forced to parachute from damaged planes often landed on friendly territory and could return to action soon afterward.

questions.question: Which ancient nation is the name Gustav related to?

quizzes.title: History Quiz: King and July
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, franks, death. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This King of the Franks conquered Italy and was crowned Imperator Augustus on 25 December 800.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Charles the Great

questions.question: What King of England had his nephews put into the Tower of London?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Richard III

questions.question: What English Queen was daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elizabeth I

questions.question: Which of these countries fought on the side of Britain during the Battle of Britain?
What dynasty ruled France before the Capetian dynasty?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Carolingian dynasty

questions.question: Franz Joseph I reigned as King of Hungary, King of Bohemia and Emperor of Austria.
How were Napoleon Bonaparte and Napoleon III related?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Uncle and nephew

questions.question: What King of France was popularly known as the Sun King?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Louis XIV

questions.question: What monarch transformed the Tsardom of Russia into the Russian Empire?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Peter I the Great

questions.question: What General was named Commander of the UN forces in Korea on July 8, 1950?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Douglas MacArthur

questions.question: What song hit # 1 on the Billboard Charts on July 9, 1955?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rock around the Clock

questions.question: What Civil War battle ended on July 3, 1863 with a Union victory?
Who was sworn in as the 13th President on July 10, 1850 following the death of President Zachary Taylor?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Millard Fillmore

questions.question: How was Catherine the Great of Russia related to Petar III?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: She was his wife.

questions.question: Frederick I Barbarossa, who was crowned Holy Roman Emperor in 1155, belonged to what royal dynasty?
